sentences: You proved your worth out there. I mean, it wasn’t just about pulling the trigger. You took to this life like it was always inside you, waiting to be unleashed.
This ain’t some Disney movie, but you… you aimed for the stars in your own way.
What did I do before all this? You said something about a music career.
Yeah. Best guitarist in the area, at least that’s what I heard. I was never much into the punk scene, but you were the shit, Blake. People talked about you.
But you know how it goes. Same old story. Your band split up, and you tried going solo… didn’t exactly pan out the way you wanted, did it? You had to trade one stage for another.
Like a dance, right?
Yeah, exactly like a dance. But you were never one for subtle moves, not the “stealthy” type.
You had this calm about you, a kind of stillness before the chaos. But the moment the cameras rolled, when it was time to perform… you stepped onto that stage and owned it.
But I was still killing people. Isn’t that wrong? I mean… at the end of the day, it’s blood on my hands.
Look, everybody knows what they’re getting into when they play this game. “Fuck around and find out,” that’s the rule out there. This job—it comes with risks. You knew that before you even started.
Hell, I knew it when I got into this.
We all end up the same way eventually, one way or another.
Listen, Blake. People out there, they play with fire. They think they’re untouchable, that the darkness won’t get to them. But when they’re caught in it… they realize the truth.
It’s a dance, remember? Everyone’s got a role to play. And you—you were just playing yours. The system’s rigged, kid. You did what you had to do.
I don’t know. Sometimes it just feels… wrong. Like I’m losing myself in it.
You’re not losing yourself, Blake. You’re finding who you really are. Out there, in the chaos, you’re free. It’s the only place you’ve ever felt alive, isn’t it?
I don’t know if I’d call it freedom. It feels more like… drowning.
Drowning? Maybe. But sometimes you gotta drown a bit before you learn to swim. And you, kid—you’ve been swimming in this darkness longer than you think.
You’re stronger than you give yourself credit for.
So, what now? What was the next move?
You remember that spot near Glenwood? The old metro station, the one where the trains don’t stop anymore. It was abandoned.
I sent you there with a simple task—just to drop off a note. A message, the paper kind. Nothing flashy. You just had to slip it into one of those old lockers and walk away.
